data.title: Sophie's World Travel Inspiration
data.meta_description: The Bremen town musicians play a lead in this pretty Hanseatic city in northern Germany. But there's much more to Bremen, of course. Here's a little taste.
data.text:
A donkey, a dog, a cat, a rooster ‚Äì you‚Äôre looking at the famous Bremen Town Musicians.

This 200-year-old Grimms brothers‚Äô fairytale is about four friends, all a bit worse for wear and mistreatment at the hands of abusive owners. Well, nothing for it, only one thing to do: escape! But where to? ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs go to Bremen, yo ‚Äì and set up as buskers‚Äô.

These four may be old and weary, but they‚Äôre not lacking in the clever wits department. On the way to Bremen, see, they encounter a gang of thieves. By standing on each other‚Äôs backs and making a combined strange noise, they outwit the crooks. They steal the (stolen) goods, eat the thieves‚Äô food, and take over their house. Later, when one of the thieves returns to investigate, Cat scratches his face, Dog bites his leg, Donkey gives him a good kick and Rooster screams. But Thief had a different experience: a scary witch scratched his face, a man knifed his leg, a monster hit him with a club, and a judge screamed from the rooftop. It‚Äôs all about perspective.

And here they are, the four clever ones, one on top of the other, staring through the window at the thieves‚Äô feast, forever captured in bronze by Gerhard Marcks. You‚Äôll find it outside the town hall, near the entrance to the restaurant Ratskeller.

PS If you‚Äôve seen something like this before, but you‚Äôre pretty sure you‚Äôve never been in Bremen, you may very well have been in the Latvian capital (on a stag do, perhaps? üòâ) In Riga a few weeks ago, I happened to walk past this on SkƒÅr≈Üu Street during the golden hour:

Now, these four in Riga aren‚Äôt staring at thieves feasting, but rather through the Iron Curtain and into the brave new world outside, suddenly available for the taking, after Gorbachev opened the curtain. Humorous, high level politics here. Sculpted by Bremen artist Krista Baumgaertel, this was a gift from Bremen to its sister city.

But back to the promised land. Or, at least, that‚Äôs how Bremen must have appeared to our four friends.

This Hanseatic city is of course more than a place to get your musical career started. It‚Äôs also really pretty and really cosy, so best you spend a night or two. However, if all you have is a day (and how often isn‚Äôt that the case‚Ä¶ sigh!), it‚Äôs less than an hour away from Hamburg by train ‚Äì an easy daytrip.

Like L√ºbeck, Bremen is sweet as. Not marzipan sweet here, but Hachez, distinguished chocolate manufacturers since 1890.

Also like L√ºbeck, Bremen was an Imperial Freistadt, a Free City, subject only to the emperor. But unlike L√ºbeck, which lost that status in 1937, Bremen has retained the title (Hamburg has, as well). Not that it means much; it doesn‚Äôt come with special privileges or rights within the German federation. But it does sound cool, doesn‚Äôt it? Freistadt!

Bremen was settled 12 000 years ago. Not many traces remain from the first 11 000 years, but the last 1 000 have left their marks. There‚Äôs plenty of history, culture and ace architecture for you to experience. I‚Äôm going to focus on the gravitas of world heritage today, namely the town hall and Roland. (Who dat, you ask? Patience, dear reader, all will become clear.) But let‚Äôs start with something lighter:

M√ºhle am Wall

One of the first things you‚Äôll spot as you walk from the railway station to the old town, is this quaint century-old windmill amongst the flowers in Wallanlagen Park. What a contrast to the city fortifications that once were here. Have a wander about or have coffee in the windmill restaurant. Here it is again, in the dark of night. Cosy, innit?

Now, let‚Äôs get down to the more serious sightseeing in Altstadt, the old town:

Hanseatic Bremen

There it is again, the Hanseatic League. Bremen was one of the major HQs for that band of merchants and traders roaming the waters of Northern Europe back in medieval times. An old-fashioned EFTA, you could say ‚Äì or even the EU, in a time when things were simpler, pre-centralisation, pre-Lisbon.

The central part of Altstadt is Marktplatz, the town square. Central, both in terms of geography and importance. This is where you‚Äôll find the Gothic town hall and Roland, Here‚Äôs a night-time view of the town hall‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶ and here‚Äôs Roland, one of Charlemagne‚Äôs 12 warriors known as paladins, tirelessly protecting the city, day and night since 1404.

What‚Äôs a medieval town square without a cathedral? Here‚Äôs the 13th century St Peter‚Äôs Cathedral, or Bremer Dom:

The town hall was built in the early 1400s, in a time when opulent town halls were constructed as a form of defiance against the church. Both the upper and lower halls of Bremen town hall were a few centimetres longer and wider than that of the archbishop‚Äôs palace. Councillor vs bishop. Secular vs religious power. Mine is bigger than yours. Interesting how little things have changed.

The cathedral door is gorgeous ‚Äì

‚Äì but so is this town hall side entrance.

The cathedral doors are guarded by aggressive-looking lions and griffons, all Harry Potter-like ‚Äì

‚Äì the town hall door by a couple of muscular knights on equally muscular horses.

Hm, much as I like Harry Potter, fantastic beasts, and so on‚Ä¶

¬ß¬ß¬ß¬ß¬ß¬ß¬ß

We started easy, and we‚Äôll end easy. As you amble back to the railway station, you‚Äôll probably pass along S√∂gestrasse. Soghestrasse was this street‚Äôs name in medieval times, Soghe meaning sow. Shopkeepers here thought it would be fun to remember old times and commissioned Hirt mit Schweinen: bronze piggies with herder and dog.

It might have been a pigsty once. Today, however, you‚Äôll find high-end shops along S√∂gestrasse: Swarowski, Pandora, Rituals‚Ä¶

Another little quirk along the streets of Bremen. Feel free to sit on the pigs. Kids do.
